title: Travel briefs
text:
Lodge touts spooky events What better place to spend Halloween than the reputedly haunted Punderson Manor State Park Lodge in Geauga County?
The lodge, in what was once a private Tudor revival-style mansion, will offer
special packages on Friday (All Hallow’s Eve) and Saturday (Halloween).
The Friday event includes an evening with a psychic and paranormal investigator. Saturday includes a session with former park manager and resident historian Nick Fischbach, who has experienced many mysterious events at the lodge. Both packages include a catered group dinner and behind-the-scenes lodge tours.
Packages start at $138 a person, double occupancy.
For information, call 1-800-282-7275 or visit www.pundersonmanorstateparklodge.com .
Halloween part of camping If spooky camping is your style, Hocking Hills State Park will have special programs for campers on Friday and Saturday nights.
The Haunted Hocking “investigation team” will take park guests on a search for the unexplained beginning at 7 p.m. Saturday with a hike into Ash Cave, which is supposedly haunted by a shadowy figure of a woman in 1920s clothing.
Camping guests can also enjoy pumpkin decorating, hayrides, trick-or-treating and a costume parade.
For information, call 740-385-6842 or visit www.hockinghillsstatepark.com .
1,500-bloom mum on view Longwood Gardens’ annual chrysanthemum festival, which runs through Nov. 22, includes what the garden calls “the largest chrysanthemum in the Western world,” with more than 1,500 flowers.
The festival has more than 16,000 chrysanthemums groomed and trained into a variety of shapes, such as balls, spirals and cascades.
The garden is in Kennett Square, Pa. Details are at www.longwoodgardens.org .
Iran expects tourism boom Iran’s vice president said recently his country is preparing for a “tsunami” of foreign tourists as a result of a landmark nuclear deal that is to lift sanctions in return for curbs on Iran’s nuclear program.
Visa rules are to be eased for Iran, which is home to 19 UNESCO-registered sites.
In 2014, more than 5 million tourists visited, generating $7.5 billion in revenue.
— From staffand wire reports
